--- Chad Bohannan <chad@...> wrote:
> I've been thinking about using 'conflicting'
> networks/controllers
> operating the same set of inputs and outputs. 
> My thoughts revolve around a weighted summing device
> that recieves both
> the ouput and an associated confidence from each
> network, and the output
> of the system is a function of the confidence levels
> ( sudden rise in
> confidence having more meaning than a steady state
> confidence ) and the
> outputs of the functions.
> This approach might allow for a coupling of
> seemingly incompatable
> networks or controllers, such as a LSTM to recognize
> features in a
> landscape, an evolved neural network for obsticle
> avoidence, and a
> conventional controller for 'after-market' behaviour
> add-ons, with out
> re-evolving or re-teaching the previous networks.
> The idea sounds like fun, except that I have no idea
> how to go about
> teaching anything how to describe how confident it
> is in its own output.
> Any thoughts? 

Well, you could always add one more output to any ANN,
and this output ranges from 0 to 1, 0 meaning no
confidence and 1 meaning complete confidence.  I don't
see how to apply that to any particular problem
though.  Can you give us a detailed example of the use
of such an ANN?

=====
Mitchell Timin
